entries.title: Iowa Birth and Early Beginnings
entries.description: Lindy Achen began his life in 1902, born on October 7th in Remsen, Iowa. This period marks his earliest beginnings, before his family's significant move to Canada. It was a time of infancy and early childhood, setting the stage for his future experiences on the prairie.

excerpts.text: and go back and start relating the story from where I was born at Remsen, Iowa, October the 7th, 1902.

entries.title: Early Years: Iowa and Saskatchewan
entries.description: These early years, around 1905-1907, were formative for young Lindy, spent initially in Remsen, Iowa. His memories suggest a period of transition, hinting at a significant event that stretched back to 1907. This year marked a pivotal moment: the family's move to Saskatchewan, Canada, and the beginning of his life on the prairie farm.

excerpts.text: - be a long drawn-out affair as my memory goes back to the year 1907 when
And now we're talking into 1905.

entries.title: Prairie Childhood: Work and Growth
entries.description: From 1911 to 1916, young Lindy Achen experienced the demanding life of a farm boy on the Canadian prairies. He worked alongside his family, contributing to construction projects like a new barn and pasture, and enduring long days of physical labor. These years shaped his work ethic and provided a foundation for his future career in construction.

excerpts.text: he put down the foundation everything then we had to haul all those rock in to fill that foundation in and then filled it up with sand so they could put a four inch coat of cement all over the barn it was an up-to-date barn everything was first class. That's when I was 13 years old that fall, the fall of 1915. You want to know about work, well that was work and that same
And as soon as we were able to work, I can remember when they built that pasture in 1914, I guess it was, that they used to haul us a mile and a half away, and we'd dig post holes all day
That would take us through the years of about 1916, '17, I'd say, somewhere in there.
In the summer when I was, what, 1915, I was 13 years old that fall.
I think it was the winter of '16 when J.P. was married.

entries.title: Prairie Years: Shadows of War
entries.description: For Lindy, 1917 was a difficult year, marked by hardship and short harvests on the family farm in Saskatchewan. The period around 1916-1918 was remembered as a time that 'went fast,' with the looming presence of World War I and the subsequent influenza pandemic impacting his life and the prairie community.

excerpts.text: Around about that time went fast, 1917, 1917, that was the year, no 1918 was when the flu hit.
That would take us through the years of about 1916, '17, I'd say, somewhere in there.
And that's all it takes through '17, 1918, still home on the farm.
Then, '17 is a short crop, '18 was a short crop.
1917, bad, kind of a bad year.

entries.title: Prairie Years: Flu and Tractors
entries.description: In 1918, sixteen-year-old Lindy Achen continued to work on his family's farm in Saskatchewan, facing a short harvest and the devastating impact of the influenza pandemic which arrived in the spring. His father purchased a Titan tractor during this time, marking a shift in farm technology, while the family relied on livestock and self-sufficiency to weather the hardships.

excerpts.text: 1918 short crop. 1919 less crop again but we always fared somehow we had a lot of always raised 50 60 hogs for sale and we always had hens, 125 hens around so we had our own eggs our own pork had our own beef we always had 50 60 head of cattle and about that many horses so you're never short on work
Around about that time went fast, 1917, 1917, that was the year, no 1918 was when the flu hit.
And Dad bought a... Oh, in the meantime, 1918, he had bought a little Titan tractor.
And that's all it takes through '17, 1918, still home on the farm.
That was '18, and '19 we dried out, totally dried out.

entries.title: Prairie Years: Drought and Locusts
entries.description: During 1919-1920, seventeen and eighteen-year-old Lindy Achen experienced severe drought conditions on the family farm in Saskatchewan, impacting crop yields and requiring resourcefulness to survive. The following year brought a devastating grasshopper infestation that nearly wiped out their harvest, highlighting the precariousness of life on the prairie. Despite these hardships, the family maintained a substantial livestock operation, providing a degree of self-sufficiency.

excerpts.text: 1918 short crop. 1919 less crop again but we always fared somehow we had a lot of always raised 50 60 hogs for sale and we always had hens, 125 hens around so we had our own eggs our own pork had our own beef we always had 50 60 head of cattle and about that many horses so you're never short on work
But in the end, you got very little crop out of it. It was probably five bushel to the acre so and that took us through '20. '21, a good crop a good crop that could ...
In 1920, the grasshoppers came in, and they just really come in clouds, you know, ... poison a whole quarter section.
1920, the hoppers came in and just about cleaned us out.
That was '18, and '19 we dried out, totally dried out.

entries.title: Prairie Harvest and Changing Times
entries.description: In 1921, nineteen-year-old Lindy Achen was deeply involved in farm work in Saskatchewan, operating machinery and experiencing the relief of a good harvest after a difficult year. This period also marked significant personal changes, including his brother Joe's departure and a sense of isolation on the farm with his brother Mac. It was a time of new technologies like radios and separators, and the beginning of a shift in Lindy's life trajectory.

excerpts.text: But in the end, you got very little crop out of it. It was probably five bushel to the acre so and that took us through '20. '21, a good crop a good crop that could ...
And then it was the fall of '21. Dad bought a little separator to go with the little Titan tractor we had.
And as it was then, that was '21. Then that fall, Joe left. He went to the coast.
I was running the thrashing outfit, and I run that same outfit then in 1921.
So Mac and I were home alone on the farm then through '21, '22.

entries.title: Prairie Harvest and Early Learning
entries.description: During 1922-1923, Lindy was a young man of twenty and twenty-one, living and working on the family farm in Saskatchewan. This period was marked by bountiful harvests and a focus on practical skills, including learning to maintain the farm's telephone system. It also saw his mother's departure for California and potentially his first experience with radio technology.

excerpts.text: In the winter of '22, I came to Regina and took a telephone course in order to be able to maintain the telephones at home, the local rural telephone.
Maybe later than that, it could have been '22 or '23, I heard my first radio.
And the winter of twenty - the fall of '23, mother went to California.
So Mac and I were home alone on the farm then through '21, '22.
The fall of '23, Mother had gone to California.

entries.title: Loss, Farm, and Sudden Responsibility
entries.description: 1924 was a pivotal year for Lindy, marked by the sudden death of his father and the immediate responsibility of managing the family farm in Saskatchewan. At just 22 years old, he shouldered the burden of running the farm while his mother traveled from Portland for the funeral, signaling a significant shift in his life trajectory.

excerpts.text: mother,  mother got there by train it's funny how you could move around in those days. She'd come all the way from portland and we only held the funeral two days, I think. She was there for the funeral. And then I was in charge of the farm starting right then and there so that was in 1924 and uh
I have a few minutes to go before I go for coffee, so I'll just continue about the years before 1924.
I'm getting the story a bit mixed up, but I'll go back to 1924.
That was the summer of 1924, my first year of running the farm.
And, oh yes, in '24, in '24, yeah, we had finished.

entries.title: Prairie Roots, Power's Dawn
entries.description: From 1925 to 1930, Lindy experienced a period of transition, marked by successful harvests and growing tensions with his brothers that led him to leave the family farm. He began a career in electrical work, laying the foundation for his future construction business and embarking on a lifelong journey with rural power lines, a field that would define much of his later life.

excerpts.text: Well, I operated that for about a year and a half and then the company saw fit to build a line from Gull Lake to Tompkins and shut that down. Now we're into 1930 we're into 1930 - yeah I operated the plant '35, '36 into the spring of '37 and uh -
I started working on power in 1927, and then I worked until just about the end of '45 for various companies.
'26, some of the boys came up from California, and they thought Mother was paying me too much money.
The old line, which had been built in 1928, we had a salvage 60 miles a line.
So that's the way it went from - a lifetime in power from 1928 to 1965.

entries.title: Prairie Years: Work and Transition
entries.description: From 1931 to 1934, Lindy navigated a period of fluctuating employment, initially working for the Power Commission before taking a leave of absence and returning to the family farm. He spent time at home, then in Tompkins, and ultimately pursued electrical work, gaining experience and laying the groundwork for his future construction business. This era was marked by both hardship and opportunity as he honed his skills and considered his next steps.

excerpts.text: And when I think back through the years from about '31 when I started working for the Power Commission, and I mentioned that earlier, and then I only worked for them eight months, and I took a leave of absence and I never went back.
It was in 1934 that the electrician - the inspector who used to come through there said to me one day, "Why don't you write your journeyman's paper?" he said, "You're a good electrician."
And then the spring of '34, Dubois, the superintendent, this was still the same company that was in Estevan, he said, "I'm putting you down in Gull Lake to do some wiring there.
So I worked in the summer of '34, '35, part of '33 at 50 cents an hour, and paid my own room and board.
I think I related earlier that I had started doing some inside wiring way back in 1931.

entries.title: Prairie Power and Changing Lines
entries.description: From 1935 to 1939, Lindy Achen worked as an electrician and power plant operator in Saskatchewan, initially running a plant before it was superseded by a new power line to Tompkins. He spent these years maintaining lines, calibrating meters, and occasionally assisting at other locations like Gravelbourg and Shaunavon, marking a period of technical work and travel across the prairies.

excerpts.text: Well, I operated that for about a year and a half and then the company saw fit to build a line from Gull Lake to Tompkins and shut that down. Now we're into 1930 we're into 1930 - yeah I operated the plant '35, '36 into the spring of '37 and uh -
And then in '36, they decided they were going to run a power line from Gull Lake to Tompkins, and abandoned this little power plant.
In the spring of '38, I went out and relieved out at Gravelbourg in Lafleche while they changed operators out there.
So I worked in the summer of '34, '35, part of '33 at 50 cents an hour, and paid my own room and board.
And in the fall of '38, I was sent out to Shaunavon and Gravelbourg to calibrate meters.

entries.title: Marriage, Work, and Constant Duty
entries.description: From 1940 to 1944, Lindy Achen was married and deeply involved in his construction business, likely related to wartime efforts. He faced a demanding schedule, frequently on call and working extended hours, coinciding with the construction of an airport in Estevan. This period marked a significant shift towards a life of constant responsibility and intense labor.

excerpts.text: And they were building an airport in Estevan, around '42, and ... one hell of a place to work.
Then the airport came in in 1941, so it was really a busy time around there.
Then I was in charge of the lines there for the rest of '37, '38, '39, '40.
And there's '41, '42, '43, '44, on call, 24 hours a day, 30 days a month.
Married on the end of November in '40.

entries.title: Prairie Contractor, Post-War Years
entries.description: 1945 marked a significant shift for Lindy Achen, as he established himself as an independent contractor, focusing on building rural power lines across Saskatchewan. He was actively bidding on tenders and working closely with individuals like Ted Durnan, solidifying his construction business and transitioning from working for various companies. The period also saw the completion of an airport and a move back to Regina, signifying a period of both professional growth and geographic movement.

excerpts.text: The tenders ranged - now this is in 1945 dollars. You can multiply that by five for today. The first tender opened up, $11,000; the next one, $11,500; the next one, $11,075, and then mine was the last one, $10,050. Well here I was just
I started working on power in 1927, and then I worked until just about the end of '45 for various companies.
The Fall of '45, when I finished the airport, I came into Regina here and did some work.
I'll give you a history of my years of contracting, which was from 1945 to 1965.
Now I'm a contractor on my own, and the time is the end of September 1945.

entries.title: Prairie Lines and Labor
entries.description: The years 1946-1950 were a period of significant expansion for Lindy's Achen Construction, marked by the construction of a major power line to Stoughton and other projects across Saskatchewan. He faced labor challenges with strikes among his workers, reflecting the changing dynamics of the post-war era. These years represent a key phase in establishing his company's presence in rural electrification.

excerpts.text: ,in those days, I'm talking back in 1946, up to 1950, I had a bunch go on strike up - way up north of Swift Current.
We're talking now the end of 1945 and 1946, the '46 -
I built that big line to Stoughton in '46.
Yes, I even did some in 1945 or '46.
That was in fourty - '46...

entries.title: Prairie Lines, Forty-Five Years
entries.description: In 1947, Lindy Achen was actively managing crews and expanding his Achen Construction business, focused on building rural power lines across Saskatchewan. He recounts multiple projects, including work from Weyburn to Radville and finishing up a season of construction. At 45 years old, he was deeply immersed in the work that would define his career.

excerpts.text: 1947, my first job was building a line from Weyburn to Radville and picking up the village of Trossachs on the way.
And as the funny says - Fools Hesitate, Funny McGee. Well, that was the end of 1947.
There's no interference from the wind, so I'll go on talking about 1947 now.
And I want to go back now to 1947, when I was running the two crews.
to finish up at Yorkton from the fall of '47.

entries.title: Shifting Gears, Moving Forward
entries.description: 1948 appears to be a year of significant transition for Lindy Achen, marked by a sense of needing to 'make definite moves' and a struggle to recall the specifics of his work. He was likely involved in finishing projects from Rosetown and tendering for new work, possibly related to his construction business building rural power lines, while also relocating to Regina sometime in the spring.

excerpts.text: and moved up here. It was still spring there was a lot of snow I think we come up about - maybe about the end of march or the middle of april sometime in there we moved to Regina. Now, I didn't have any work for '48 we had to tender. Well I still had a little work to finish up at Rosetown and a little
The spring of 1948, I could see then things were going to move ahead, and I had to make some definite moves.
The price had been established back in, when, '50 - '48 or '50, somewhere in there, had been established.
And I have to really think hard now to think of where I worked in '48. In '48...
And incidentally, I might mention that in 1948,

entries.title: Prairie Lines and Alberta Winds
entries.description: In 1949, Lindy Achen and Achen Construction were actively building rural power lines across Saskatchewan, Canada. His work extended into Alberta, involving projects like securing a high-voltage line from Killaly and servicing numerous farms. This period marked a busy time for his company, filled with travel and construction across the prairies.

excerpts.text: Another time we had built a line up in Alberta, I may have said that earlier. And Art Miller was up there. This was way back in '49.
And in '49, I went to - oh yeah, I got the piece of high voltage line, the 72,000 from Killaly,
Previous to that, in '49, I can't recollect where we were working.
From there, moved down to - oh, I forgot to tell you, in '49.
Well, anyway, that was the start of '49. Now I have -

entries.title: Prairie Lines and Union Roots
entries.description: The year 1950 marked a period of intense activity for Lindy and Achen Construction, with numerous power line projects spanning across Saskatchewan, from Yorkton to Bienfait and the Ogema-Shaunavon area. This was also a time of establishing a contractors' union, reflecting the growing need for worker representation within the industry. Lindy, at 48, was deeply involved in the physical labor and business dealings of expanding rural electrification.

excerpts.text: anything that come up no matter what it was. And they let the other guys get by. Some of them set up little one-horse offices but didn't have anybody in there to man it, so they were no better off but that was one of the things they asked for and never got. But I don't know to relate back - Oh, we had a contractors' union. We started that way back in about 1950.

And then down in the Ogema - Shaunavon area, yeah, Fife Lake, and in that area we did a bunch of towns there in '50, '51, we were in the Ogema–Bengough, and in through there we did 60 or 70 miles of line in a bunch of towns.
And that wound her up to '50 - '51. We went up north in the Rosetown area and we had a big job up there, a lot of three-phase transmission line and about probably
Then in '50, I started out. Built that line from Yorkton to Theodore and from there, Lampman to Bienfait, that was another 18 miles.
,in those days, I'm talking back in 1946, up to 1950, I had a bunch go on strike up - way up north of Swift Current.

entries.title: Prairie Lines and Busy Years
entries.description: The years 1950-1951 were a period of intense work for Lindy and Achen Construction, focused on building extensive three-phase transmission lines and power lines across Saskatchewan, particularly in the Rosetown, Ogema, and Shaunavon areas. He personally oversaw much of the work, including setting poles in newly developed suburbs, marking a significant and demanding season in his career.

excerpts.text: And then down in the Ogema - Shaunavon area, yeah, Fife Lake, and in that area we did a bunch of towns there in '50, '51, we were in the Ogema–Bengough, and in through there we did 60 or 70 miles of line in a bunch of towns.
And that wound her up to '50 - '51. We went up north in the Rosetown area and we had a big job up there, a lot of three-phase transmission line and about probably
I set all the poles in all the suburbs that were built from 1951.
Yeah, then '51, then I got a whole bunch of line.
Big season that was in '51.

entries.title: Powering the Prairie Farms
entries.description: In 1952, Lindy Achen's Achen Construction was heavily involved in building rural power lines across Saskatchewan, connecting farms to the electrical grid. This period marked a significant expansion of their farm program, with a rapid increase in the number of farms served each year. Lindy, at age 50, oversaw a demanding workload, dealing with materials and a short building season.

excerpts.text: And we were punching through, I think, at '52, about 350 farms, and then we jumped up to 500 or better every year for '53, '54, '55, '56.
We were out building all these lines in from - starting about '52 is when the farm program really started.
We got so much a pole, so much an anchor, so much a transformer, from 1952 through to 1957.
Then we really swung into the farm building in '52, '53.
And then '52 - and then the farms started picking up.

entries.title: Incorporation and Rapid Growth
entries.description: 1953 marked a pivotal year for Lindy Achen, as he incorporated his business and experienced a period of rapid expansion in his rural electrification work. He oversaw the construction of new facilities and significantly increased the number of farms served, while also grappling with the complexities of managing a growing company and establishing fair wages for himself. This era was characterized by intense activity and a relentless drive to connect rural communities with power.

excerpts.text: five or six years when I - when I incorporated and I never did change my wages then in the - from '53 to '65 in 12 years I still took $1,000 a month, but I was taking up big bonuses at the end of the year -
And we were punching through, I think, at '52, about 350 farms, and then we jumped up to 500 or better every year for '53, '54, '55, '56.
I built an office and a shop in '53, and it was too small the day I built it, and it's still operating.
And when I incorporated then in 1953, I didn't know what wages I should draw.
Then we really swung into the farm building in '52, '53.

entries.title: Prairie Expansion and Power Lines
entries.description: Around 1954, Lindy Achen's construction company was rapidly expanding its rural electrification work across Saskatchewan, significantly increasing the number of farms they served each year. This period was marked by intense labor and challenges, including a severe sleet storm that disrupted communication infrastructure. Lindy, at 52, was deeply involved in this demanding phase of his career.

excerpts.text: And we were punching through, I think, at '52, about 350 farms, and then we jumped up to 500 or better every year for '53, '54, '55, '56.
Oh, in 1954, they had a big sleet storm in Manitoba, and they took down all the telephone lines in southern Manitoba.
That was the pace we were hitting in '53, '54, '55
It was '54.

entries.title: Powering the Prairie, Heart and Hustle
entries.description: The mid-1950s were a period of intense growth for Achen Construction, with the company rapidly expanding its rural electrification work across Saskatchewan. Lindy, at 53, was deeply involved in this expansion, leading a team that was consistently adding hundreds of farms to their network each year. Tragically, 1955 also marked a significant personal setback with a heart attack that temporarily sidelined him.

excerpts.text: And we were punching through, I think, at '52, about 350 farms, and then we jumped up to 500 or better every year for '53, '54, '55, '56.
In '55, when I had my heart attack, you know, I was right out of it.
And '55, well, we did some towns and villages in that, too.
That was the pace we were hitting in '53, '54, '55
And I wasn't - In '55 and '56

entries.title: Powering the Prairie Landscape
entries.description: The mid-1950s marked a period of significant expansion for Achen Construction, as Lindy and his team dramatically increased the number of farms they electrified across Saskatchewan. Lindy, in his early fifties, oversaw a surge in productivity, reaching upwards of 600 farms serviced in 1956 alone, building upon steady growth from previous years. This was a time of intense work and visible impact on the rural landscape.

excerpts.text: And we were punching through, I think, at '52, about 350 farms, and then we jumped up to 500 or better every year for '53, '54, '55, '56.
And it went up to about 450 farms in '56.
I think we did about 600 farms in '56.
started about 1956 or 7, about '57.
We wound up, again, '56 more farms.

entries.title: Tapering Down, Filling In
entries.description: Around 1957, Lindy's large-scale farm operation was winding down, transitioning from building large units of farms to more scattered work. His construction business, Achen Construction, was still heavily involved in building rural power lines, though the intensity of that work began to lessen after this point. This period marked a shift in Lindy's focus and activities.

excerpts.text: '57 now the farm operation the big units of 40 and 50 farms are pretty well all done. We're doing a scattered filling -
We got so much a pole, so much an anchor, so much a transformer, from 1952 through to 1957.
And I just finished saying that we were - in '57, we were filling in farms.
Well, after '57, I kept Art Miller in the shop to more or less
Then in '57, it started tapering down.

entries.title: Dust Settles, Business Shifts
entries.description: 1958 appears to have been a challenging year for Lindy, marked by a lack of work and being 'bit out' of projects. He was navigating business setbacks, expanding his office, and dealing with the aftermath of events that left many of his men based in Regina. The year signifies a period of transition and adjustment within Achen Construction.

excerpts.text: Yeah, when the dust was settled in '58, well, I had my men, most of them were in Regina here.
Well, anyway, to get back to '58, when I was bid right out, didn't have any work.
I expanded the office in 1958, I think it was,
When they opened their wide up in '58,
And I'm still talking back in '58.

entries.title: Prairie Years: A Slow Rebound
entries.description: 1959 appears to be a transitional year for Lindy, following a period of uncertainty. While he acknowledges it wasn't a 'big' year, he notes a sense of things 'picking up again' and completion of activities. It likely falls within his period of building rural power lines across Saskatchewan, a significant part of his career.

excerpts.text: And the next year, in '59, things started picking up again.
In '59, what did we do in 59?
Yeah, '59 was not a big year.
And we kept going, '59 -
And that completed '59.

entries.title: Building Lines, Bidding, and Years
entries.description: The years 1960-1963 were a period of continued expansion for Achen Construction, with Lindy overseeing the building of power lines and bidding on significant projects like the Shellbrook to Prince Albert line. He was actively managing his company and hiring new employees, though recalling the specifics of this time became increasingly difficult as the years passed. This era represented a busy and productive phase in his career, continuing his work electrifying rural Saskatchewan.

excerpts.text: Then in '61, Rags Johnson and ourselves jointly bid on a piece of high-voltage line from Shellbrook to Prince Albert, which had a river crossing in it, which was always a big job.
Then '63. Trying to think, in '63 - as the later years come come in it's harder for me to remember what the hell we were doing. And -
And then Con Bandy, another guy that started working for me in '63, or '62, somewhere in there.
'60 another one of those years where it was a little work here, and a little work there.
Then it come along '60 and I build - then I got quite a bit of line in '60.

entries.title: Prairie Power and Passing Years
entries.description: The years 1963 and 1964 found Lindy deeply involved in his construction business, specifically building rural power lines across Saskatchewan. This period marked a continuation of work he'd begun two decades prior, as he neared the end of that significant chapter in his life, likely reflecting on his past and the changes he'd witnessed.

excerpts.text: That was '63 and '64.

entries.title: Retirement and Achen Construction
entries.description: The years surrounding 1965 mark a significant turning point for Lindy, as he sold his interests in Achen Construction and formally retired from a lifetime of building rural power lines. He felt burned out and transitioned into a new phase of life, though a company bearing his name continued under different ownership. This period also involved a complex business arrangement with Art, solidifying a new chapter after decades of dedicated work.

excerpts.text: five or six years when I - when I incorporated and I never did change my wages then in the - from '53 to '65 in 12 years I still took $1,000 a month, but I was taking up big bonuses at the end of the year -
I've enjoyed relatively good health, considering that when I quit, I - when I quit in 1965, I was pretty well burned out.
With Art - they set up a company, Achen '65 Limited, and Art was the 51% shareholder.
I'll give you a history of my years of contracting, which was from 1945 to 1965.
No strings attached." Except they made it Achen Construction, 1965 Limited.

entries.title: Retreat and Reflection
entries.description: Around 1966, Lindy Achen began to transition out of the business he had built, selling his stake in Achen Construction between 1965 and 1967. This marked a significant shift after decades of hard work and expansion, likely offering him a chance for reflection and a new chapter in his life at the age of 64.

excerpts.text: This is in '66 - yeah that's -
I sold out in '65, '66, '67.
